channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [GROOVY-3732] Groovyc throws exception in code using ASTTransformations
item.description:
For the GParallelizer build the tests are not compilable. Neither with Gradle nor with an Ant build. The following ant build:

<?xml version="1.0"?>
<project name="sample" default="resolve">
    <target name="clean">
        <delete dir="antbuild/classes"/>
    </target>
    <taskdef name="groovyc"
             classname="org.codehaus.groovy.ant.Groovyc">
        <classpath>
            <pathelement path="/Users/hans/checkouts/gparallelizer-read-only/libs/groovy-all-1.6.4.jar"/>
        </classpath>
    </taskdef>

    <target name="compile">
        <mkdir dir="antbuild/classes"/>
        <groovyc srcdir="${basedir}/src/main/groovy" destdir="${basedir}/antbuild/classes">
            <classpath>
                <pathelement path="/Users/hans/checkouts/gparallelizer-read-only/libs/groovy-all-1.6.4.jar"/>
                <pathelement path="/Users/hans/checkouts/gparallelizer-read-only/libs/jsr166y-070108.jar"/>
            </classpath>
            <javac source="1.5" target="1.5" debug="on"/>
        </groovyc>
    </target>

    <target name="compileTests" depends="compile">
        <mkdir dir="antbuild/test-classes"/>
        <groovyc srcdir="${basedir}/src/test/groovy" destdir="${basedir}/antbuild/test-classes">
            <classpath>
                <pathelement path="${basedir}/build/classes"/>
                <pathelement path="/Users/hans/checkouts/gparallelizer-read-only/libs/junit-4.7.jar"/>
                <pathelement path="/Users/hans/checkouts/gparallelizer-read-only/libs/groovy-all-1.6.4.jar"/>
                <pathelement path="/Users/hans/checkouts/gparallelizer-read-only/libs/jsr166y-070108.jar"/>
            </classpath>
            <javac source="1.5" target="1.5" debug="on"/>
        </groovyc>
    </target>
</project>

throws an exception when executing ant compileTests. Below is a snippet from the stacktrace. I have attached the full stacktrace of the ant execution. The revision of GParallelizer where we hit this problem is 559.

compileTests:
  [groovyc] Compiling 158 source files to /Users/hans/checkouts/gparallelizer-read-only/antbuild/test-classes
  [groovyc] org.codehaus.groovy.control.MultipleCompilationErrorsException: startup failed, General error during semantic analysis: Type ActorMessage not present
  [groovyc] 
  [groovyc] java.lang.TypeNotPresentException: Type ActorMessage not present
  [groovyc]     at sun.reflect.generics.factory.CoreReflectionFactory.makeNamedType(CoreReflectionFactory.java:98)
  [groovyc]     at sun.reflect.generics.visitor.Reifier.visitClassTypeSignature(Reifier.java:107)
  [groovyc]     at sun.reflect.generics.tree.ClassTypeSignature.accept(ClassTypeSignature.java:31)
  [groovyc]     at sun.reflect.generics.visitor.Reifier.reifyTypeArguments(Reifier.java:50)
  [groovyc]     at sun.reflect.generics.visitor.Reifier.visitClassTypeSignature(Reifier.java:120)
  [groovyc]     at sun.reflect.generics.tree.ClassTypeSignature.accept(ClassTypeSignature.java:31)
  [groovyc]     at sun.reflect.generics.repository.FieldRepository.getGenericType(FieldRepository.java:67)
  [groovyc]     at java.lang.reflect.Field.getGenericType(Field.java:223)
item.summary: Groovyc throws exception in code using ASTTransformations

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
The following code:

#! /usr/bin/env groovy

@Grapes ( [
         @Grab ( group = 'org.gparallelizer' ,  module = 'GParallelizer' , version = '0.8.3' ) ,
         //@GrabConfig ( systemClassLoader = true )
         ] )

import org.gparallelizer.actors.Actor
import org.gparallelizer.actors.BoundedThreadActor

public class Test_Grab_GParallelizerActors {
  public static void main ( final String[] args ) {
    final Actor actor = new BoundedThreadActor ( )
    println ( actor )
  }
}

Also exhibits the same problem I think:

org.codehaus.groovy.control.MultipleCompilationErrorsException: startup failed:
General error during class generation: Type ActorMessage not present

java.lang.TypeNotPresentException: Type ActorMessage not present
at sun.reflect.generics.factory.CoreReflectionFactory.makeNamedType(CoreReflectionFactory.java:116)
at sun.reflect.generics.visitor.Reifier.visitClassTypeSignature(Reifier.java:125)
at sun.reflect.generics.tree.ClassTypeSignature.accept(ClassTypeSignature.java:49)
at sun.reflect.generics.visitor.Reifier.reifyTypeArguments(Reifier.java:68)
at sun.reflect.generics.visitor.Reifier.visitClassTypeSignature(Reifier.java:138)
at sun.reflect.generics.tree.ClassTypeSignature.accept(ClassTypeSignature.java:49)
at sun.reflect.generics.repository.FieldRepository.getGenericType(FieldRepository.java:85)
at java.lang.reflect.Field.getGenericType(Field.java:241)
at org.codehaus.groovy.vmplugin.v5.Java5.configureClassNode(Java5.java:273)
at org.codehaus.groovy.ast.ClassNode.lazyClassInit(ClassNode.java:259)
at org.codehaus.groovy.ast.ClassNode.getUnresolvedSuperClass(ClassNode.java:925)
at org.codehaus.groovy.ast.ClassNode.getUnresolvedSuperClass(ClassNode.java:920)
at org.codehaus.groovy.ast.ClassNode.getSuperClass(ClassNode.java:914)
at org.codehaus.groovy.ast.ClassNode.isDerivedFrom(ClassNode.java:857)
at org.codehaus.groovy.classgen.AsmClassGenerator.assignmentCastAndVisit(AsmClassGenerator.java:3976)
at org.codehaus.groovy.classgen.AsmClassGenerator.evaluateEqual(AsmClassGenerator.java:3929)
at org.codehaus.groovy.classgen.AsmClassGenerator.visitDeclarationExpression(AsmClassGenerator.java:1343)
at org.codehaus.groovy.ast.expr.DeclarationExpression.visit(DeclarationExpression.java:53)
at org.codehaus.groovy.classgen.AsmClassGenerator.visitAndAutoboxBoolean(AsmClassGenerator.java:4038)
at org.codehaus.groovy.classgen.AsmClassGenerator.visitExpressionStatement(AsmClassGenerator.java:1331)
at org.codehaus.groovy.ast.stmt.ExpressionStatement.visit(ExpressionStatement.java:40)
at org.codehaus.groovy.ast.CodeVisitorSupport.visitBlockStatement(CodeVisitorSupport.java:35)
at org.codehaus.groovy.ast.ClassCodeVisitorSupport.visitBlockStatement(ClassCodeVisitorSupport.java:161)
at org.codehaus.groovy.classgen.AsmClassGenerator.visitBlockStatement(AsmClassGenerator.java:694)
at org.codehaus.groovy.ast.stmt.BlockStatement.visit(BlockStatement.java:51)
at org.codehaus.groovy.ast.ClassCodeVisitorSupport.visitClassCodeContainer(ClassCodeVisitorSupport.java:97)
at org.codehaus.groovy.ast.ClassCodeVisitorSupport.visitConstructorOrMethod(ClassCodeVisitorSupport.java:108)
at org.codehaus.groovy.classgen.AsmClassGenerator.visitStdMethod(AsmClassGenerator.java:573)
at org.codehaus.groovy.classgen.AsmClassGenerator.visitConstructorOrMethod(AsmClassGenerator.java:549)
at org.codehaus.groovy.ast.ClassCodeVisitorSupport.visitMethod(ClassCodeVisitorSupport.java:119)
at org.codehaus.groovy.classgen.AsmClassGenerator.visitMethod(AsmClassGenerator.java:651)
at org.codehaus.groovy.ast.ClassNode.visitContents(ClassNode.java:997)
at org.codehaus.groovy.ast.ClassCodeVisitorSupport.visitClass(ClassCodeVisitorSupport.java:50)
at org.codehaus.groovy.classgen.AsmClassGenerator.visitClass(AsmClassGenerator.java:261)
at org.codehaus.groovy.control.CompilationUnit$11.call(CompilationUnit.java:728)
at org.codehaus.groovy.control.CompilationUnit.applyToPrimaryClassNodes(CompilationUnit.java:935)
at org.codehaus.groovy.control.CompilationUnit.compile(CompilationUnit.java:468)
at groovy.lang.GroovyClassLoader.parseClass(GroovyClassLoader.java:282)
at groovy.lang.GroovyClassLoader.parseClass(GroovyClassLoader.java:253)
at groovy.lang.GroovyClassLoader.parseClass(GroovyClassLoader.java:190)
at groovy.lang.GroovyShell$2.run(GroovyShell.java:204)
at java.security.AccessController.doPrivileged(Native Method)
at groovy.lang.GroovyShell.run(GroovyShell.java:202)
at groovy.lang.GroovyShell.run(GroovyShell.java:148)
at groovy.ui.GroovyMain.processOnce(GroovyMain.java:494)
at groovy.ui.GroovyMain.run(GroovyMain.java:309)
at groovy.ui.GroovyMain.process(GroovyMain.java:295)
at groovy.ui.GroovyMain.processArgs(GroovyMain.java:112)
at groovy.ui.GroovyMain.main(GroovyMain.java:93)
at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)
at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:57)
at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:43)
at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:616)
at org.codehaus.groovy.tools.GroovyStarter.rootLoader(GroovyStarter.java:108)
at org.codehaus.groovy.tools.GroovyStarter.main(GroovyStarter.java:130)
Caused by: java.lang.ClassNotFoundException: ActorMessage
at java.net.URLClassLoader$1.run(URLClassLoader.java:217)
at java.security.AccessController.doPrivileged(Native Method)
at java.net.URLClassLoader.findClass(URLClassLoader.java:205)
at java.lang.ClassLoader.loadClass(ClassLoader.java:323)
at groovy.lang.GroovyClassLoader.loadClass(GroovyClassLoader.java:664)
at groovy.lang.GroovyClassLoader.loadClass(GroovyClassLoader.java:763)
at java.lang.ClassLoader.loadClass(ClassLoader.java:268)
at java.lang.ClassLoader.loadClassInternal(ClassLoader.java:336)
at java.lang.Class.forName0(Native Method)
at java.lang.Class.forName(Class.java:264)
at sun.reflect.generics.factory.CoreReflectionFactory.makeNamedType(CoreReflectionFactory.java:113)
... 54 more

1 error

The relevant class is in the jar file though:

> jar tvf /home/share/Software/Java/GParallelizer-0.8.3.jar grep ActorMessage
1077 Thu Sep 03 14:43:18 BST 2009 org/gparallelizer/actors/ActorMessage.class
>

Unless it can be shown that there is a fault in GParallelizer, this is a blocking issue as it means Groovy is preventing GParallelizer from building.

NB The code builds and passes its tests on Eclipse and I think IntelliJ IDEA, which indicates it is not a GParallelizer bug.

I think it is a fault in GParallelizer (I don't know much about the project, so in turn it can again be a groovy problem depending on how its classes are generated)

In the class AbstractThreadActor, which BoundedThreadActor extends, there is this field called messageQueue, which is of the type BlockingQueue<ActorMessage>

The fault there is that the bytecode signature for this field declaration is <Ljava/util/concurrent/BlockingQueue<LActorMessage;>;>, whereas it should have been
<Ljava/util/concurrent/BlockingQueue<Lorg/gparallelizer/actors/ActorMessage;>;>

Because the full class name for the generic parameter ActorMessage is being written as "ActorMessage" and not as "org/gparallelizer/actors/ActorMessage", java
is not able to see the class.

We need to see how the class file for AbstractThreadActor is being generated and why is the field declaration has the wrong type information written in the bytecode.

I looked into the GParallelizer source code and now I know how various classes are implemented / generated.

The issue reported is there with the joint-compilation. It is not handling the generics very well, I think.

I created the following dummy classes to reproduce the issue:

// *************************AbstractThreadActor.groovy *************************

package org.gparallelizer.actors

import java.util.concurrent.*

public class AbstractThreadActor {
    final BlockingQueue<ActorMessage> messageQueue;
}

// ************************* ActorMessage.java *************************
package org.gparallelizer.actors;

class ActorMessage {}

With the above setup, the field messageQueue in AbstractThreadActor gets generated as
<Ljava/util/concurrent/BlockingQueue<LActorMessage;>;>, which is wrong.

If I implement ActorMessage class as ActorMessage.groovy so that all class generation is in groovy, then the field
signature comes fine as <Ljava/util/concurrent/BlockingQueue<Lorg/gparallelizer/actors/ActorMessage;>;>

So, the problem is with join compilation and class generation here.

I have never looked into join-compilation implementation of groovy. Can someone please point me to the relevant code?

Is there a bit of documentation on how join-compilation works?

I looked into the joint compilation a bit and here is the sequence of things of interest:

1) JavaAwareResolveVisitor visits ClassNode org.gparallelizer.actors.AbstractThreadActor.

  • It visits the field BlockingQueue<ActorMessage> messageQueue and tries to resolve ActorMessage.
  • By this time the JavacJavaCompiler has not compiled ActorMessage.java - so resolve of ActorMessage fails. JavaAwareResolveVisitor identifies it as an error but does not take any action on the error (it has overridden addError() to do nothing).
  • Since the resolve error of ActorMessage does not make compiler fail, the field BlockingQueue<ActorMessage> messageQueue gets visited successfully with ActorMessage resolved as just "ActorMessage".

2) JavaStubGenerator generates the stub for ClassNode org.gparallelizer.actors.AbstractThreadActor

3) JavacJavaCompiler now compiles ActorMessage.java

4) Anymore resolve calls to BlockingQueue<ActorMessage> find BlockingQueue as already resolved from 1) above, so don't try to do resolve its genericsTypes again. So, ActorMessage never gets a chance to become org.gparallelizer.actors.ActorMessage post joint-compilation (JavacJavaCompiler).

I have no idea right now on how to go in the fix direction.

Any suggestions?

doesn't sound fully right to me. True addError i overwritten, but JavaAwareResolveVisitor is thought to resolve only what it can. If it failed and the class is still marked as resolved, then this is a bug. For joint compilation it still will be only ActorMessage, because we hope the java compiler will do the resolving for this then. As long as the according import is there, it should work in almost all cases.

So the bug would be in ResolveVisitor or JavaAwareResolveVisitor, because a class should never be set as resolved if JavaAwareResolveVisitor failed.

Jochen, I think your explanation holds good for a simpler case where field type uses no generics.
But with generics used in joint compilation, the situation is a bit different.

So, say, in the simpler case, the type AbstractThreadActor is defined as:

package org.gparallelizer.actors

import java.util.concurrent.*

public class AbstractThreadActor {
    ActorMessage messageQueue;
}

In this case the JavaAwareResolveVisitor is not able to resolve ActorMessage and leaves it
as is and when JavacJavaCompiler has compiled the Java class, in the next resolve() call, it
gets resolved fine.

However, when the AbstractThreadActor is defined as:

package org.gparallelizer.actors

import java.util.concurrent.*

public class AbstractThreadActor {
    BlockingQueue<ActorMessage> messageQueue;
}

then the primary type (type of the field messageQueue) that is getting resolved is
BlockingQueue and although JavaAwareResolveVisitor fails to resolve ActorMessage (and also leaves
ActorMessage unresolved correctly), the type BlockingQueue gets marked as resolved.

Now after JavacJavaCompiler has compiled ActorMessage class, when further resolve() calls are
made for the field messageQueue's type BlockingQueue, it is found resolved already and resolve
logic does not touch its generics types because the resolve logic works as:

    private boolean resolve(ClassNode type, boolean testModuleImports, boolean testDefaultImports, boolean testStaticInnerClasses) {
        if (type.isResolved() || type.isPrimaryClassNode()) return true;
        resolveGenericsTypes(type.getGenericsTypes());
        .....
    }

That's where the error is coming from.

Any suggestions?

One option that can be probably be tried is to make a small change as below so that resolveGenericsTypes() call
is made even if the primary type is resolved:

private boolean resolve(ClassNode type, boolean testModuleImports, boolean testDefaultImports, boolean testStaticInnerClasses) {
        resolveGenericsTypes(type.getGenericsTypes());
        if (type.isResolved() || type.isPrimaryClassNode()) return true;
        .....
}

If the generic type has been resolved earlier, additional call to resolveGenericsTypes() wouldn't really
add much overhead as they would return back fast. This little overhead will be there only when generics are being used.

And in cases like joint-compilation, where it is possible that generic types are not resolved yet, it will help in resolving them.

Any issues seen with that approach?

Attaching the patch for review.

After applying the patch, I have done a local gparallelizer ant build to verify that the class being generated has the correct generics signature for messageQueue field now that was causing the reported issue.

I applied the patch and tried to run this script:

@Grab('org.gparallelizer:GParallelizer:0.8.3')
import org.gparallelizer.actors.Actor
import org.gparallelizer.actors.BoundedThreadActor

final Actor actor = new BoundedThreadActor()
println actor

I still get this error:

java.lang.TypeNotPresentException: Type ActorMessage not present
Caused by: java.lang.ClassNotFoundException: ActorMessage

What I had done was that I built groovy with this change, pointed gparallelizer build file to this newly built groovy and then done the gparallelizer build and seen that the class built had the current field signature in its bytecode.

Not sure you can do that with @Grab (unless gparallelizer gets rebuilt with groovy that has my patch).

I don't know much about @Grab, but wouldn't it fetch gparallelizer 0.8.3 from some common place (maven repository)? If that is the case, then first gparallelizer has to be re-built with the groovy build that has my patch and only then the script with @Grab() will go through. The offending gparallelizer class has to be re-compiled with changes in groovy compiler that my patch is introducing.

What do you say?
It seems that GParallelizer builds using Gradle compiling against my patched Groovy trunk 17601. I guess this means a 1.6.5 as well as merging this patch into HEAD?

Russel, I will deliver the fix on the branches required. Please have patience.

The patch is currently shared for review. Usually I get comments from Jochen very fast.

Applied the patch on trunk and 1.6.5 branch.

Since I had tested the gparallelizer build locally and I also got a confirmation
of the same from Russel, I have gone ahead with delivering the fix.

Just for completeness, I made a local GParallelizer SNAPSHOT and this script now works:

@Grab('org.gparallelizer:GParallelizer:0.8.5-SNAPSHOT')
import org.gparallelizer.actors.Actor
import org.gparallelizer.actors.BoundThreadActor

final Actor actor = new BoundThreadActor()
println actor

Excellent work Roshan!
Thanks for the kind words, Paul - for a 3-liner change whose explanation I repeated 4 times in my excitement in y'day's comment
Thank you Roshan for fixing the bug so promptly. Much appreciated.
Happy to be of use, Vaclav.
As far as I can see Subversion Trunk HEAD now works fine for building GParallelizer. Thanks Roshan.

My pleasure, Russel.

Through this JIRA, I got a chance to finally look at a bit of how joint compilation works. I had been wanting to see that area for some time but been lazy. Now I at least know what are the important pieces there and how they are fitting together.
